caption: Table 1: Comparison of the restoration results over ten different datasets. The best results are marked in boldface.
description: This table compares the performance of UIR-LORA with other state-of-the-art image restoration models on ten different datasets.  The metrics used for comparison include PSNR (higher is better), SSIM (higher is better), LPIPS (lower is better), and FID (lower is better).  The table also shows the model complexity in terms of parameters and runtime.  The boldfaced values indicate the best performance for each metric across all models.

caption: Table 2: Comparison of the restoration results on mixed degradation datasets. The best results are marked in boldface.
description: This table presents a comparison of image restoration results on two mixed degradation datasets: REDS and LOLBlur.  Several state-of-the-art models are evaluated, and their performance is measured using PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID metrics.  The best performance for each metric on each dataset is highlighted in bold. This table demonstrates the ability of the proposed UIR-LoRA model to handle mixed degradations effectively.

caption: Table 3: Impact of strategies in router
description: This table presents a comparison of the performance of different strategies used in the degradation-aware router of the UIR-LORA model for both multiple and mixed degradation scenarios.  The strategies tested include randomly activating LoRAs, using average weights, and selecting top-K most similar LoRAs (Top-1, Top-2, and All). The table shows the PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID scores for each strategy, highlighting the effectiveness of the proposed Top-K strategy based on degradation similarity.

caption: Table 4: The accuracy of predicted degradation type
description: This table presents a comparison of image restoration results using two methods: the original method and a modified method.  The metrics used to compare these methods include PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID. The table also includes the accuracy of the predicted degradation type for each method. The modified method demonstrates improved performance across all metrics, indicating an enhancement in accuracy and efficiency.

caption: Table 1: Comparison of the restoration results over ten different datasets. The best results are marked in boldface.
description: This table compares the performance of the proposed UIR-LORA model against several state-of-the-art image restoration methods across ten different datasets.  The metrics used for comparison include PSNR (Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio), SSIM (Structural Similarity Index), LPIPS (Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity), and FID (Fréchet Inception Distance). Higher PSNR and SSIM values indicate better restoration quality, while lower LPIPS and FID values suggest improved perceptual similarity to the ground truth images. The table also shows the model's complexity in terms of the number of parameters and the runtime required for processing each image. This allows for a comprehensive comparison of the different models' performance, efficiency, and visual quality.

caption: Table 1: Comparison of the restoration results over ten different datasets. The best results are marked in boldface.
description: This table presents a comparison of image restoration results across ten different datasets using various state-of-the-art models, including the proposed UIR-LORA.  Metrics used for comparison include PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID.  Higher PSNR and SSIM values indicate better image quality, while lower LPIPS and FID scores suggest better perceptual quality. The table also lists the number of model parameters and the runtime for each method.

caption: Table 1: Comparison of the restoration results over ten different datasets. The best results are marked in boldface.
description: This table compares the performance of different image restoration models across ten datasets, evaluating their effectiveness in terms of PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID.  Higher PSNR and SSIM scores indicate better restoration quality (lower distortion), while lower LPIPS and FID scores reflect improved perceptual quality and better alignment with the ground truth. The best performing model for each metric is highlighted in bold.

caption: Table 1: Comparison of the restoration results over ten different datasets. The best results are marked in boldface.
description: This table compares the performance of UIR-LORA against other state-of-the-art image restoration models across various metrics (PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, FID).  The results are presented for ten different datasets, highlighting the superior performance of UIR-LORA in terms of distortion and perceptual quality, as well as model complexity and runtime.

caption: Table 1: Comparison of the restoration results over ten different datasets. The best results are marked in boldface.
description: This table compares the performance of UIR-LORA with other state-of-the-art image restoration models across ten different datasets.  The metrics used for comparison include PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID, which measure different aspects of image quality.  Higher PSNR and SSIM values indicate better image quality, while lower LPIPS and FID values indicate better perceptual quality. The table also shows the model's complexity in terms of parameters and runtime, providing a comprehensive comparison of the models' performance and efficiency.

caption: Table 1: Comparison of the restoration results over ten different datasets. The best results are marked in boldface.
description: This table compares the performance of the proposed UIR-LORA model against several state-of-the-art image restoration methods across ten different datasets.  The metrics used for comparison include PSNR (Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio), SSIM (Structural Similarity Index), LPIPS (Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity), and FID (Fréchet Inception Distance). Higher PSNR and SSIM values indicate better image quality, while lower LPIPS and FID values represent higher perceptual similarity to ground truth images.  The table also shows the model complexity in terms of the number of parameters (Param/M) and runtime (Runtime/s) for each model, providing a comprehensive comparison of both performance and efficiency.
